c.v: Before you get started using the tool, there are a few things that are useful to know:

SEAD Инструмент оценки уличного освещения v1.7.6a

- A key feature of the tool is the ability to compare many different fixtures. By uploading IES files, you can build a large library of possible fixtures, and then analyze them all for a specific road configuration to see which achieves the best light quality and energy consumption

- Calculations are based on the IESNA calculation method; however, several simplifying assumptions have been made to allow for implementation in a simple spreadsheet tool. Therefore, results shouldn't be used for verifying compliance with these standards, but rather allow you to get a first pass at identifying the fixtures that are likely to provide the best energy performance for your requirements, which you can then analyze in detail using lighting design software.
- The tool is designed to be simple to use, requiring little prior knowledge. Follow the steps, and look out for popup boxes and "?" links for additional information
'Windows button' -> Excel Options -> Trust Center -> Trust Center Settings

A second use of the tool is to decide which specific fixture to use to get the best lighting performance. This may be to choose from a few specific fixture options, or to evaluate a manufacturer's claim that a certain fixture will match the light quality provided by your current fixtures. To evaluate specific fixtures:
All results will be archived to the MResults tab, and show up in MGraphs.

By default, all results are resorted by energy consumption when a new scenario is saved. If you wish to view them sorted by another method (fixture name, pole spacing, etc), you can use the sort feature of Excel on rows 4 and below of the MResults tab. Alternately, you can move the data on this tab to another workbook to create your own graphs and analyses.
Contact the manufacturer or visit their website to download the electronic IES files for the fixtures you're considering
Follow steps 1-5 on the inputs page to define your current configuration, desired target light levels, and relevant costs
Follow steps 1-5 to define your road configuration, desired target light levels, and relavant costs
Follow steps 1-5, choosing the appropriate comparison type of single fixture or multiple fixtures in step 3
For a description of the other tabs and what they contain go here:

If only analyzing a single fixture, use the "Save Single Upgrade" button to save the scenario to the MResults tab. If analyzing multiple fixtures, the fixtures will be saved when you click 'Run Selected Fixtures'
Instructions for potential applications of the tool:
Macros are required to perform the lighting calculations. To use the tool, you must enable macros. To do this:
Most steps are self explanatory, but for a few pointers on a specific application, see these links:
Not all tabs are needed by the user, but all tabs are left open so that you can see how calculations are performed if needed. Here's a description of all the tabs in the tool:

Simplest comparison is to compare one baseline fixture (the existing fixture, or standard choice for a new fixture) to an upgrade fixture. To do this, follow steps 1-5 as outlined on the Inputs tab, ignoring the options for 'analyze multiple fixtures' The SResults tab will show the results, and the MGraphs and MResults tabs may be ignored.
The 'baseline' scenario can be ignored, or you can use the 'No fixture' fixture choice to set energy consumption of the baseline shown in the graphs to zero
The inputs tab gives you access to all required inputs, as well as navigation to all the other tabs relevant to the user. Start here, and if you get lost come back here and find the appropriate step.
The MGraphs page will show you which fixtures pass and fail your illuminance criteria for the given road geometry, ranked in order of lowest to highest energy consumption.

The primary use of the tool is to quickly evaluate the potential energy and life cycle cost savings from replacing existing fixtures with energy efficient fixtures. To do this, the tool has been pre-populated with a variety of typical fixtures, and allows you to enter the specifics of your current road and pole configuration. To do this:

This tool is designed to provide a simple, easy way of doing detailed street lighting photometric analysis. Whether you're an experienced designer, a procurement official looking to verify manufacturer claims, or a policy person wanting to know the magnitude of potential energy savings, we hope this tool will be something you find useful. Before you get started, here are a few notes on the capabilities - and limitations - of the tool:
To compare additional scenarios , after saving the results you may change the inputs for the other steps and save the new results
Trusted publishers tab, click Trust all installed add-ins and templates

Use the Add IES file button in step 3 to add this data to the tool. Be sure to check default values for fixture life, cost, and lumen depreciation in the Fixtures tab and make sure they are appropriate for your fixture
When choosing the upgrade fixture in Step 3, choose 'Multiple Fixtures' option and select some or all of the generic typical fixtures

While the tool is not designed to find optimal pole spacing, pole height and other variables that can be more easily changed in new construction, the tool does allow you to save a specific design scenario so you can compare it to other scenarios. You can save single scenarios (with a specific upgrade fixture), or run multiple fixtures for each scenario and compare all batches of results. To do this:
- If TM 21 results are not available, ask for LM-80 test results, or comparable tests. This is the test method for determining LED depreciation at different junction temperatures.

- Ask the manufacturer to provide information about the junction temperature of their fixtures at different ambient outdoor temperatures. The biggest factor that reduces LED life is the temperature of the actual LED junction; a well designed fixture will be able to dissipate and have cooler junction temperatures.

- With long LED life, other electronic components in the fixture may fail before the LED's. To guard against this, ask about surge protection, water sealing, and any certification or testing on the electronic components in the fixture.

-Additionally, ask for estimates of how fixture life will vary based on outdoor temperature. This is determined by combining information from LM-80 with the actual fixture design. While you may not be able to assess the accuracy of this information, it can provide an indication of how much the designer has thought about proper heat dissipation

Assumed material-only cost of replacing the bulb or fixture at the end of the assumed fixture life. For HPS fixtures, the default assumption includes both the actual bulb cost as well as the average cost for the portion of fixtures that need to be replaced when bulbs are replaced. For LED fixtures, typically the whole fixture must be replaced so this is the cost of a new fixture.

Fixture life is the assumed number of hours that the lamp can operate before the bulb needs replacing. This life corresponds to the assumed Replacement Bulb Cost for life cycle cost calculations. In the case of HPS fixtures, this life is of the bulb; the equipment cost of a bulb replacement is the typical cost of a bulb plus the average percent of fixtures that will also need to be replaced when bulb replacement occurs. In the case of LED fixtures, most manufacturers do not provide independent bulbs, so this refers to the life of the entire fixture.

Fixture technology used - high pressure sodium (HPS) or Light Emitting Diode (LED). The value is for reference, and for use in determining default fixture and bulb costs and lamp lumen depreciation. Other lamp types (low pressure sodium, metal halide, etc) can be defined in either category if assumptions of cost and life are adjusted appropriately

For LED fixtures , fixture life can be very long - but a poorly designed fixture may have a much shorter life than typical. It's very important to assess manufacturer claims about typical life. To assess these claims, here are some tips:

If the actual ballast used in a lamp differs from the standard reference ballast used for photometric testing, the lamp may produce more or less light; this factor adjusts the photometric data for a lamp up or down if a different ballast is to be used.

Light loss factor is the ratio of design condition light output to initial light output. This includes Lamp Lumen Depreciation (LLD), Luminaire Dirt Depreciation (LDD), and Temperature Effects. As a lamp ages, it produces less light than it did initially; different fixtures may also change at different rates. Lighting design should be done to the level that the lamp will be at end of life, rather than at the beginning. You may need to adjust the dirt depreciation assumption for your location; lamp lumen depreciation should be tied to the assumed fixture life.

Note that some manufacturers don't follow proper format when providing the power and don't include the ballast power. Therefore, it's very important to check the wattage assumptions when adding a fixture. One indication that a fixture doesn't include the ballast is if the watts are the same as the nominal wattage for that fixture (e.g. 150 watts for a 150 watt fixture) - actual power including ballast is usually higher. LED fixtures don't measure bulb power separately and will usually be correct.

Refers to the material-only cost of replacing an entire fixture; labor cost is reported separately. This is used in the life cycle cost assessment, but is only used for the initial installation cost. Fixture replacement for maintenance should be built into the bulb replacement assumption.
This is actual power consumption of the fixture, including the bulb and any ballast or other electronics. It is read in from the IES file when other fixture data is captured.
Luminance and Illuminance calculations can be done based on either IES or CIE standard. The output file reflects the method chosen here.

Several standards define appropriate lighting levels for roadway lighting. These include IESNA standard RP-8, CIE standard 115, and several country specific standards. The inputs in this section do not impact the results of specific fixture scenarios, but do provide comparison points for evaluating whether a fixture configuration provides sufficient light quality

IESNA Classification Definitions
Road Classifications
Freeway: A divided major roadway with full control of access (no crossings at grade). This definition applies to toll as well as non-toll roads. Freeway A: Roadways with greater visual complexity and high traffic volumes. Usually this type of freeway will be found in major metropolitan areas in or near the central core and will operate through some of the early evening hours or darkness at or near design capacity. Freeway B: All other divided roadways with full control of access. Major: The part of the roadway system that serves as the principal network for through-traffic flow. The routes connect areas of principal traffic generation and important rural roadways leaving the city. Collector: Roadways servicing traffic between major and local streets. These streets are used mainly for traffic movements within residential, commercial and industrial areas. They do not handle long, through trips. Collector streets may be used for truck or bus movements nad give direct service to abutting properties. Local: Local streets are used primarily for direct access to residential, commercial, industrial, or other abutting property. They make up a large percentage of the total street system, but carry a small proportion of vehicular traffic.
Pedestrian Conflict Are Classifications
High: Areas with significant numbers of pedestrians expected to be on the sidewalks or crossing the streets during darkness. Examples are downtown retail areas, near theaters, concert halls, stadiums, and transit terminals. Medium: Areas where lesser numbers of pedestrians utilize the streets at night. Typical are downtown office areas, blocks with libraries, apartments, neighborhood shopping, industrial, older city areas, and streets with transit lines. Low: Areas with very low volumes of night pedestrian usage. These can occur in any of the cited roadway classification but may be typified by suburban single family streets, very low density residential developments, an rural or semi-rural areas.
Pavement Classification
R1 (mostly diffuse) - Portland cement concrete road surface. Asphalt road surface with a minimum of 12 percent of the aggregates composed of artificial brightener (e.g. Synopal) aggregates (e.g., labradorite, quartzite). R2 (mixed diffuse and specular) - Asphalt road surface with an aggregate composed of a minimum 60 percent gravel (size greater than 1 cm). Asphalt road surface with 10 -15 percent artificial brightener in aggregate mix. R2 (slightly specular) - Asphalt road surface (regular and carpet seal) with dark aggregates (e.g. trap rock, blast furnace slag); rough texture arfter some months of use. R4 (mostly specular) - Asphalt road surface with very smooth texture.

IESNA established the RP-8-05 standard practice for roadway lighting. The standard takes into account both traffic and pedestrian volumes and serves as the basis for design of fixed lighting for roadways, adjacent bikeways, and pedestrian ways.
In the 2005 version of the standard, both illuminance and luminance methods can be used. This tool calculates both methods by default; for the luminance method, you must choose the 'IES' in 'Calculation Assumptions per...' to use the appropriate IESNA assumptions in the calculations. Below is the information for both methods.
The illuminance method derives its recommended values by evaluating roadway type, level of pedestrian conflict and pavement classification. Roads are divided into five categories: freeways, expressways and majors have high traffic and collector and local roads handle less traffic. Pedestrian conflict refers to the amount of pedestrian traffic and the category is divided into high, medium, and low. Pavement is grouped into four classification based on the mode of reflectance ranging from mostly diffuse to mostly specular.
Precise classifications as defined by IESNA are listed below Table 1.
Illumination Engineering Society of North America (IESNA)
Note CIE Uo is the inverse of IES Uo; value should be IES method, greater than one
Table 1: IESNA Illuminance Method - Recommended Values
Table 2: CIE Parameters for the Selection of M Lighting Class
Table 3: CIE Lighting classes for motorized traffic

The CIE 115:2010 standard uses a luminance based lighting standard. The standard takes into account many variables characterizing both the traffic on the road and the road layout. This is used to determine a lighting class from M1 to M6, with M1 roads having the greatest need for lighting. The CIE standard does not take into account pedestrian traffic.
Table 2 is used to assign a traffic route a lighting classification, ranging from M1 to M6, according to the function of the road, the design speed, the overall layout, the traffic volume and composition, and the environmental conditions.
Table 3 defines the lighting criteria for lighting classes M1 to M6.
The lighting class is calculated as: M = 6 - Vws This calculation will result in a class number between 1 and 6. If the result is not a whole number, use the next lower whole number.
View Description of a Standard Below:

IESNA Classification Definitions
Road Classifications
Freeway: A divided major roadway with full control of access (no crossings at grade). This definition applies to toll as well as non-toll roads. Freeway A: Roadways with greater visual complexity and high traffic volumes. Usually this type of freeway will be found in major metropolitan areas in or near the central core and will operate through some of the early evening hours or darkness at or near design capacity. Freeway B: All other divided roadways with full control of access. Expressway: A divided major roadway for through traffic, with partial control of access and generally wieht interchanges at major crossroads. Expressways for noncommercial traffic within parks and park-like areas are genearlly known as parkways. Major: The part of the roadway system that serves as the principal network for through-traffic flow. The routes connect areas of principal traffic generation and important rural roadways leaving the city. Collector: Roadways servicing traffic between major and local streets. These streets are used mainly for traffic movements within residential, commercial and industrial areas. They do not handle long, through trips. Collector streets may be used for truck or bus movements nad give direct service to abutting properties. Local: Local streets are used primarily for direct access to residential, commercial, industrial, or other abutting property. They make up a large percentage of the total street system, but carry a small proportion of vehicular traffic.
Pedestrian Conflict Are Classifications
High: Areas with significant numbers of pedestrians expected to be on the sidewalks or crossing the streets during darkness. Examples are downtown retail areas, near theaters, concert halls, stadiums, and transit terminals. Medium: Areas where lesser numbers of pedestrians utilize the streets at night. Typical are downtown office areas, blocks with libraries, apartments, neighborhood shopping, industrial, older city areas, and streets with transit lines. Low: Areas with very low volumes of night pedestrian usage. These can occur in any of the cited roadway classification but may be typified by suburban single family streets, very low density residential developments, an rural or semi-rural areas.
Pavement Classification
R1 (mostly diffuse) - Portland cement concrete road surface. Asphalt road surface with a minimum of 12 percent of the aggregates composed of artificial brightener (e.g. Synopal) aggregates (e.g., labradorite, quartzite). R2 (mixed diffuse and specular) - Asphalt road surface with an aggregate composed of a minimum 60 percent gravel (size greater than 1 cm). Asphalt road surface with 10 -15 percent artificial brightener in aggregate mix. R3 (slightly specular) - Asphalt road surface (regular and carpet seal) with dark aggregates (e.g. trap rock, blast furnace slag); rough texture arfter some months of use. R4 (mostly specular) - Asphalt road surface with very smooth texture.

Illuminance Criteria: The illuminance method determines the amount of light incident on the roadway surface from the roadway lighting system. Because the amount of light seen by the driver is the portion that reflects from the pavement towards the driver, and because different pavements exhibit varied reflectance characteristics, different illuminance levels are needed for each type. The illuminance criteria gives recommendations for average maintained lux for various road and area classifications depending on the pavement type used. See Table 1 for recommended illuminance values and the uniformity ration. Veiling luminance rations must also be determined to avoid a lighting system that produces disability glare.

Luminance Criteria: The luminance method determines how "bright" the road is by determining the amount of light reflected from the pavement in the direction of the driver. The luminance criteria is stated in terms of pavement luminance, luminance uniformity and the disability veiling glare produced by the lighting system. See Table 2 for the recommended luminance design requirements, uniformity and the relationship between average luminance (Lavg) and the veiling luminance (Lv).
Average Luminance of the Road Surface (Lav)

The values of Lav are the minimum values to be maintained throughout the life of the installation for the specified lighting class(es). They are dependent on the light distribution of the luminaires, the luminous flux of the lamps, the geometry of the installation, and on the reflection propoerties of the road surface.
The calculation of the average luminance of the road surface should be carried out in accordance with CIE 140-2000.

U0 ies is the ratio of average luminance to minimum luminance, as calculated by IES and as used in the tool. The number in parentheses indicates the luminance as calculated by CIE, which is the ratio of the minimum luminance at a point to the average road surface luminance.and should be calculated according to CIE 140-2000.
Longitudinal Uniformity of Road Surface Luminance (Ul):

Ul ies is the ratio of the maximum luminance to the minimum lumance, as calculated by IES and as expected by the tool. This is the inverse of the standard CIE method, which is the ratio of the minimum to the maximum luminance along a line or lines parallel to the run of the road and should be calculated in accordance with CIE 140-2000. It is mainly a criterion relating to comfort and its purpose is to prevent the repeated pattern of high and low luminance values on a lit run of road from becoming too pronounced. It only applies to long uninterrupted sections of road.
TI is a measure of the loss of visibility caused by the disability glare from the road lighting luminaires. The formula from which it is calculated is given in CIE 140-2000.

The function of the surround ratio is to ensure that light direct on the surrounds is sufficient for the objects to be revealed. In situations where lighting is already provided on the surroundes the use of surround ratio is rendered unnecessary.
Surround ratio is defined in CIE 140-2000.
Indicate which fixtures to run with an X in the 'Include?' column below

SEAD Procurement Tool for Energy Efficient Street Lighting

This tool and accompanying street lighting technology profile are available at www.superefficient.org
Provide the full path of where the file is located on your computer, including the filename.ies
Enter a unique name you can use to identify the fixture
Use this sheet to load IES files

The installation cost should be the all-in cost for installing the fixture, including street closure costs, labor costs, etc. as relevant. If this is your baseline fixture (i.e. already installed), this cost should be zero

Enter the average cost of electricity that will be paid over the life of the fixture. If you wish to include energy cost increase assumptions, this should be done manually and entered as the average cost over the analysis period in today's currency.
Enter the assumed discount rate for calculating the net present value of future energy and maintenance cost savings
Enter the time period over which you'd like to evaluate the differences in maintenance, bulb replacement, and energy costs between the scenarios
Indicate the total number of lanes (both travel directions)
Indicate the width of each lane, in meters. All lanes are assumed to be the same width.
Indicate the width of the median. If there is no median, use zero.

Four pole placement configurations are provided:
Single-sided: Poles placed on one side of the road only
Staggered: Poles placed on both sides of the road, with poles on the B side of the road located half way between the poles on the A side
Median: Two fixtures mounted on the same pole, located in the center of the median, each facing outward toward the travel lanes.
Opposite: Poles are placed on both sides of the road exactly opposite to each other

Appropriate pole height depends on the surrounding area and road width. Narrow roads in residential areas tend to have lower pole heights, while wider roads with few nearby buildings have higher pole heights. When possible, higher pole heights are usually more cost effective as they allow wider pole spacing.
Typical Heights: Residential, 2 lane: 8 meters Residential, 4 lane: 9 meters Highway, 4 lane: 12 meters Highway, 6 lane: 15 meters

Pole spacing indicates the distance from the center of one pole to the center of the next pole.
For single-side and median pole placements, this indicates the distance from pole to pole
For staggered configurations, this signifies the distance from one pole to the next pole on the same side of the road
Distance from the pole mounting to the edge of the road. Only applies to single-side and staggered configurations.

Indicates the number of measurement points from one pole to the next, with a measurement taken at two cross-road distances per lane.
Max = 20
Per the IES calculation method, the number of points should be sufficient such that the Spacing of Grid is 5 meters, or 1/10 of the pole spacing whichever is less
Would you like to delete saved results on the Mresults tab before running the new scenario? If you do not delete, new results will be added to the table of existing results.
The assumptions below are the default costs used when adding a new IES file. They can be overwritten for each individual fixture on the 'Fixtures' tab

This cost should be the all-in equipment cost for the fixture, including the fixture purchase cost, new arm if needed, and any other miscellaneous wiring or ballast costs. If this is your baseline fixture (i.e. already installed), the fixture cost should be zero.
Enter any rebates or subsidies to be removed from the overall equipment cost on a per fixture basis.

The annual maintenance cost should reflect the cost of maintaining the fixtures and poles. This should include the cost of periodic relamping, cleaning (washing of LED fixtures), and repairs. It should include estimates of street or lane closures when relevant, on an average per fixture basis. For example, if 10% of your fixtures must be replaced every year, the maintenance cost would be 1/10 of the cost of replacing a single fixture.
Enter the estimated inflation rate of maintenance rates due to increased labor costs, etc.

This value reflects the depreciation in light output due to fixture degradation as it ages. By entering a value here, you will discount the estimated light levels to base design on the future, degraded values, ensuring that the fixture still meet your lighting criteria at end of life.

Enter the fraction of light output that actually leaves the fixture when dirty. Fixture output can be reduced due to dirt, soot, etc. Typical values can be found in appropriate lighting standards based on the cleanliness of the air and environment.
Desired fixture not available in the table below?
IES files describe the light output of a fixture. You can obtain them from fixture manufacturers

These target levels are used by the tool to filter fixture results based on whether they meet your target criteria or not. You can use the references at the bottom of the page to determine appropriate targets, or use your own documentation elsewhere.
There are many standards that define appropriate lighting levels for appropriate lighting levels for roadways. The two international standards are the Illumination Engineering Society of North America (IESNA) RP-8:2005 standard and the International Commission on Illumination (CIE) CIE 115:2010 standard. Other national organizations, national governments and municipalities define similar standards.

There are two measurements of light quality on a road - illuminance (light hitting the road) or luminance (light seen by an observer). The tool performs calculations using both methods; you may enter targets for one or the other, or both. Enter the target light level you would like your street lights to meet. You may enter values for either method, or both.

Fixture purchase costs, installation costs, and maintenance costs are entered individually for each fixture. Default values are provided based on the fixture type; to edit them, go to the Fixture selection tab
Net Present Value - Total Cost of Ownership
Inputs for both Baseline and Upgrade are required; however if there is no change in the road geometry, values in both columns can be the same
The annual increase in energy cost per year. This can be obtained from looking at past increases in rates paid to your utility company.

The SEAD tool comes with several sample fixtures; these are included for the purpose of testing the tool and should not be used for a real analysis.
Before starting an analysis you should add the appropriate fixture data. You can add additional specific fixtures by using IES files obtained from the manufacturer.

Road geometry inputs describe the size and shape of the road section, as well as the placement and size of poles. Enter values for both baseline and upgrade. If you are replacing fixtures only, enter the same values in both columns.

The fixtures below are those that have been selected for analysis in the previous step. Review the cost assumptions in the table; however if you have any edits you should make them to the larger table in the previous step (3: Choose Fixtures).
You're missing an input on the Road Geometry tab. Please fix it and try again!

The tool performs several types of cost analysis. First, it will calculate the simple payback of each upgrade compared to the baseline using using the assumptions below but ignoring inflation and discount rates. It will also calculate the net present value and the percent return on investment in each year of the investment, this time including inflation and discount.
2) Begin upload of IES files listed below
Do you want to delete the data on the Results page?
The annual increase in nominal price of electricity.
